questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the physician's office due to progressive fatigue, chest discomfort, and dyspnea. One week ago, he had an upper respiratory infection that resolved without treatment. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the last 25 years. Temperature is 38.0°C ( 100.4°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 85/67 mmHg. ECG is obtained and shown below:  

 

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is most likely to be found on physical examination of this patient?

choices.text: Drop in systolic pressure during inspiration
Absence of an inspiratory decline in jugular venous pressure

questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with fatigue, dyspnea, hypotension, and tachycardia following an upper respiratory infection, raises concern for cardiac tamponade due to pericarditis. The ECG shows electrical alternans, which refers to the beat-to-beat variations in the amplitude of the QRS complex. These changes are thought to be caused by the anterior-posterior swinging of the heart with each contraction in the fluid-filled pericardial sac. As the heart swings posteriorly, the electrical signals detected by the electrodes travel over a greater distance through the fluid, resulting in reduced voltage at the electrodes. This finding is fairly specific but not very sensitive for cardiac tamponade.  

Cardiac tamponade occurs when large amounts of fluid accumulate between the layers of the pericardium (pericardial effusion), resulting in compression of the heart. Common etiologies include infectious, trauma, metabolic, autoimmune, cancer or idiopathic. Presentation may be acute and develop over minutes (e.g. trauma) or subacute, which develops over hours to days (e.g., uremia, post-viral) when enough fluid accumulates. The classic triad of symptoms, known as the Beck triad, consists of hypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds. Other signs and symptoms include syncope, chest pain, and pulsus paradoxus. The latter refers to an abnormal decrease in the systolic blood pressure (>10 mmHg) observed during inspiration.  

Option Analysis

❌ S4 heart sound:
Incorrect: The S4 heart sound is an extra heart sound that occurs during late diastole (“atrial kick”), immediately before S1. It is associated with ventricular noncompliance seen in conditions such as hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, aortic stenosis, and hypertension. It can also occur during an acute MI due to stiffness of the involved myocardium. This patient’s presentation and ECG findings instead favor the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.   
❌ Pulsation of the nail bed:
Incorrect: Quincke's pulses refers to the capillary pulsations observed in the fingertips or lips seen in aortic regurgitation due to a widened pulse pressure. This patient’s presentation and ECG findings instead favor the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.   
❌ Slow-rising low-amplitude pulse:
Incorrect: Slow-rising low-amplitude (weak pulse with delayed peak) pulse also known as “pulsus parvus et tardus” can be seen in aortic stenosis due to left ventricular outlet obstruction. In contrast, this patient’s presentation and ECG findings favor the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.   
✅ Drop in systolic pressure during inspiration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Absence of an inspiratory decline in jugular venous pressure:
Incorrect: Kussmaul's sign refers to the absence of an inspiratory decline in jugular venous pressure seen in conditions such as constrictive pericarditis, restrictive pericarditis, and right atrial or ventricular tumors. Under normal conditions, the jugular venous pressure decreases during inspiration because the fall in intrathoracic pressure produces a “sucking effect” on venous return. In patients with constrictive pericarditis, the increase in intra-abdominal pressure during inspiration contributes to the increase in CVP, although the exact mechanism is unclear. This patient’s presentation and ECG findings instead favor the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the clinic because of progressively worsening dyspnea upon exertion and chest pain for the past 6 months. He has not had prior episodes of syncope, but he does describe moments in which he felt lightheaded and weak which improved with rest. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows an athletic young man in mild distress. Cardiac examination shows a 4/6 systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard between the apex and the left sternal border on auscultation. Palpation of the precordium leads to a sustained impulse best felt at the apex. Which of the following will most likely decrease the intensity of the murmur heard on the physical examination?
questions.solution:
This patient with dyspnea on exertion, chest pain, and a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard between the apex and left sternal border most likely has hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). HOCM is characterized by concentric hypertrophy and growth of the interventricular septum near the mitral valve. Asymmetric growth of the septum leads to a left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction during systole that causes blood to flow quickly through a small opening. This rapid flow lowers the pressure in this area (Venturi effect) and pulls the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve toward the septum, worsening the obstruction.  

An increase in preload or afterload would decrease the obstruction and murmur. A decrease in preload or afterload would increase the obstruction and murmur. Squatting or handgrip decreases the obstruction by obstructing the femoral artery, increasing total peripheral resistance, and increasing afterload.  
 
HOCM is a familial, autosomal dominant condition. Sudden cardiac death can occur due to sustained ventricular arrhythmias; therefore, a family history of sudden cardiac death at a young age is a big clue suggesting HOCM, especially on USMLE exams. HOCM is associated with Friedreich's ataxia and mutations involving the beta-myosin heavy chain and myosin-binding protein C.  



Diagnosis may be achieved based on the constellation of symptoms, cardiomegaly on chest X-ray, genetic testing, enlarged heart chambers and decreased ejection fraction on echocardiography, and electrocardiogram (ECG) showing left ventricular hypertrophy. Gross pathology shows global hypertrophy and asymmetric septal hypertrophy on the left, whereas microscopically, there is myocyte hypertrophy and myocardial fiber disarray.  



HOCM should be treated urgently due to increased risk of syncope and SCD. Treatment includes β-blockers and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers such as verapamil. These therapies are mainly directed at reducing LVOT obstruction; the reduced heart rates at rest and during exercise permits improved LV filling, which reduces LVOT obstruction. Additionally, the negative inotropy caused by these medications also alleviates LVOT obstruction.  

Option Analysis

❌ Diuretics:
Incorrect: Diuretics such as furosemide and hydrochlorothiazide act in the kidneys by increasing water excretion and decreasing preload. This effect would increase obstruction on the left ventricular outflow tract and increase the intensity of a hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur.   
❌ Nitroglycerin:
Incorrect: Nitroglycerin induces vasodilation and venodilation and decreases preload. This effect would increase obstruction on the left ventricular outflow tract and increase the intensity of a hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur.   
✅ Squatting :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Standing up:
Incorrect: Standing up decreases both preload and afterload. This effect would increase obstruction on the left ventricular outflow tract and increase the intensity of a hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur.   
❌ Valsalva maneuver :
Incorrect: The Valsalva maneuver, which is defined as forceful expiration against a closed airway, would decrease right ventricular filling and preload. This effect would increase obstruction on the left ventricular outflow tract and increase the intensity of a hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his roommate due to progressive dyspnea and chest tightness. A week ago, he had an upper viral respiratory infection that resolved spontaneously without treatment. The patient describes the chest pain as sharp, 7/10 in intensity, and relieved by leaning forward. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg. On physical examination, heart sounds are weak and jugular venous distention is present. During inspiration, a drop of 10 mmHg in the systolic pressure is noted. Which of the following can explain the drop in blood pressure observed in this patient?

choices.text: Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve
Beat-to-beat variation in the QRS complex

questions.solution:
This patient has muffled heart sounds, jugular venous distention, and hypotension (Beck’s triad), a presentation consistent with cardiac tamponade, most likely due to pericarditis secondary to a viral illness. Cardiac tamponade occurs when large amounts of fluid accumulates between the layers of the pericardium (pericardial effusion) resulting in external compression of the heart. Common etiologies include infectious, trauma, metabolic, autoimmune, cancer or idiopathic. The presentation may be acute and develop over minutes (e.g. trauma) or subacute, which develops over hours to days (e.g., uremia, post-viral) when enough fluid accumulates.  

Pulsus paradoxus is defined as a large decrease in systolic blood pressure (>10 mmHg) on inspiration, a finding often observed in cardiac tamponade; it is the direct consequence of ventricular interdependence. During inspiration, the fall in intrathoracic pressure produces a “sucking effect” which increases the venous return to the right heart. Under normal conditions, the pericardium can accommodate minor changes in heart volume with little impact on the left side of the heart. However, in conditions that limit the ability of the heart to expand (e.g., tamponade, constrictive pericarditis), the increased volume during inspiration causes bowing of the interventricular septum towards the left ventricle. This results in decreased end-diastolic volume (diastolic dysfunction) and lower stroke volume, manifested by a drop in systolic blood pressure.  







Option Analysis

✅ Ventricular interdependence:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve:
Incorrect: Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve can be observed in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM), the most common cause of death in young athletes. The anterior motion of the valve contributes to the left ventricular outlet obstruction seen in HOCM. This patient's presentation is instead consistent with cardiac tamponade.   
❌ Beat-to-beat variation in the QRS complex  :
Incorrect: Beat-to-beat variation in the QRS complex, also known as electrical alternans, is a typical ECG finding in patients with cardiac tamponade. It is a phenomenon that reflects the swinging of the heart in the pericardial fluid. It is not the cause of pulsus paradoxus.   
❌ Dilation of the aortic root:
Incorrect: Dilation of the aortic root is a possible cause of aortic regurgitation (AR). AR can present with a diastolic decrescendo murmur, hyperdynamic pulse, head bobbing, and widened pulse pressure. AR is not associated with pulsus paradoxus.    
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Viral myocarditis can cause dilated cardiomyopathy and subsequently heart failure. Symptoms of heart failure include progressive dyspnea, impaired exercise capacity, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and peripheral edema. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to sudden left-sided weakness. She reports over the past few weeks she has been experiencing worsening malaise, fevers and dyspnea on exertion, but today she woke up with weakness in her left arm. Past medical history is significant for systemic lupus erythematosus and nephropathy. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 182/85 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates erythema of the cheeks and bridge of the nose with sparing of the nasolabial folds. There is 1+ edema of the lower extremities bilaterally. Neurologic examination is significant for 3/5 weakness in the left upper extremity and a rightward gaze deviation. Cardiopulmonary examination is significant for a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex that was not heard at the last examination. Follow-up blood cultures are negative. Which of the following most accurately describes the pathophysiology underlying the clinical features observed in this patient?

choices.text: Deposition of sterile platelet thrombi over heart valves
Vasospasm of a large cerebral artery
Deposition of bacterial vegetations over heart valves
Rupture of an athersclerotic carotid plaque
Deep vein thrombosis and a patent foramen ovale

questions.solution:
Non-infective endocarditis, or marantic endocarditis, refers to endocarditis that leads to the deposition of sterile platelet thrombi over heart valves. While the pathogenesis of this disease is not fully understood, current theories postulate that endothelial injury caused by circulating cytokines due to pro-inflammatory states (such as systemic lupus erythematosus) causes the deposition and aggregation of large platelet thrombi. The acute injury caused by cytokines results in platelet deposition and migration of inflammatory mononuclear cells to form thrombi interwoven with fibrin and immune complexes. It is important to note that these vegetations are always sterile, in contrast to infective endocarditis. Non-infective endocarditis typically affects the mitral or aortic valves, which explains this patient’s holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex, suggestive of mitral regurgitation.   

The disease is most common in patients with active cancer, lupus, or other hypercoagulable disorders. It presents with similar features to infective endocarditis, such as splinter hemorrhages or stroke-like features, as seen in this patient. However, in contrast to infective endocarditis, there is a higher propensity for vegetations in marantic endocarditis to embolize. Embolization can occur to the brain (resulting in stroke-like features), the eyes (resulting in blindness), the limbs (resulting in ischemia), or the lungs (resulting in pulmonary embolism). Treatment for marantic endocarditis involves treatment of the underlying condition, as well as systemic anticoagulation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Deposition of sterile platelet thrombi over heart valves:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Vasospasm of a large cerebral artery:
Incorrect: While vasospasm of the middle cerebral artery may cause stroke-like features, it is less likely in this patient with signs and symptoms of endocarditis (e.g., fevers, malaise, new-onset holosystolic murmur).   
❌ Deposition of bacterial vegetations over heart valves:
Incorrect: While infective endocarditis remains a diagnostic possibility in this patient, it is less likely given the history of lupus as well as negative blood cultures.  
❌ Rupture of an athersclerotic carotid plaque:
Incorrect: While lupus can lead to accelerated atherosclerosis, and rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque can lead to stroke-like features, it is less likely in this patient with signs and symptoms of endocarditis (e.g., fevers, malaise, new-onset holosystolic murmur).  
❌ Deep vein thrombosis and a patent foramen ovale:
Incorrect: Patients with SLE are at risk for development of DVT due to widespread systemic inflammation. DVTs tend to present with unilateral lower extremity swelling, whereas the patient in this vignette has bilateral swelling as a result of protein loss nephropathy. Additionally, patients with a patent foramen ovale will typically not have a murmur, as blood flow across the defect is too slow to create substantial turbulence.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. At the scene, she was in severe pain and pointed to her chest. Soon after arrival, the patient loses consciousness. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 75/55 mmHg. On physical examination, there are multiple lacerations over the torso and face. Significant bruising is noted over the chest. Neck veins are distended. On chest auscultation, lung fields are clear bilaterally and heart sounds are weak. Echocardiography is obtained and shows a large pericardial effusion. Which of the following sets of hemodynamic parameters are most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has cardiac tamponade, most likely due to proximal aortic dissection within the pericardial sac. The very low blood pressure raises concern for shock. 

Shock is defined as a state of cellular and tissue hypoxia caused by reduced oxygen delivery and/or increased oxygen consumption or poor oxygen utilization. Initially, shock may be reversible, but it can become life-threatening if not treated promptly. Shock is divided according to the etiology: cardiogenic, hypovolemic, obstructive, and distributive.  

Cardiac tamponade is a form of obstructive shock, in which the heart is compressed due to increased volume within the pericardial sac. Although the heart is functioning normally, the external compression by the accumulated fluid impedes the volume that can be ejected from the ventricles, and as a result, cardiac output is decreased. In an attempt to compensate for the low cardiac output, systemic vascular resistance rises, which in turn increases preload. A characteristic finding seen in cardiac tamponade is the equalization of the right atrial pressure, right and left ventricular diastolic pressures, and pulmonary arterial diastolic pressures due to this extrinsic compression of the heart.    

In all types of shock, it is important to determine the underlying cause as each has a different treatment. In cardiac tamponade, the only definitive treatment is to relieve the obstruction with pericardiocentesis.  

 

Option Analysis

❌   Cardiac output (CO)  Preload   Systemic vascular resistance (SVR)  ↓  ↓  ↑ :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with hypovolemic shock (e.g., bleeding), in which low volume results in low cardiac output and low preload. The SVR rises in an attempt to compensate for the low volume. 
✅   Cardiac output (CO)  Preload   Systemic vascular resistance (SVR)  ↓  ↑ ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌   Cardiac output (CO)  Preload   Systemic vascular resistance (SVR) ↑ ↓   ↓ :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with distributive shock seen in sepsis or anaphylaxis. In patients with distributive shock, the SVR drops from massive vasodilation, and as a result, the preload decreases as well. In an attempt to compensate for the low blood pressure, cardiac output rises. 
❌   Cardiac output (CO)  Preload   Systemic vascular resistance (SVR)  ↓  ↓   ↓  :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with distributive neurogenic shock seen in CNS injuries (brain and/or spinal cord). The injury disrupts the autonomic pathways, resulting in decreased vascular resistance, myocardial depression, and altered vagal tone.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with chest pain for the past two days. The pain started gradually and is located in the center of her chest. It is slightly better when she sits up straight, and it is not affected by exertion or rest. The patient also reports feeling fatigued, achy, and feverish for the past few months. She takes no medications, and family history is non-contributory. The patient does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. The patient’s temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 153/97 mmHg. She appears anxious and uncomfortable. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and bilateral pitting ankle edema, and a scratching extra heart sound between the apex and sternum is heard on auscultation. Laboratory studies show the following:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium   132 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Hemoglobin   7.2 g/dL 
 Reticulocyte count  4.5% 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  20 U/L 
 Alanine aminotransferase  18 U/L 
 Bilirubin, Total  3.4 
 Bilirubin, Direct  0.3 
 Lactate dehydrogenase  368 U/L 
ECG shows the following:


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons    
Which of the following additional laboratory findings is most likely to be present in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is most consistent with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The classic presentation of SLE is a reproductive-age woman with arthralgias, fevers, and rash; however, because autoantibodies can attack and damage any organ system in the body, there are a wide range of symptoms and laboratory findings that can suggest a diagnosis of SLE, as seen with this patient. This patient’s chest pain is most likely due to pericarditis, as evidenced by the constant nature, improvement with sitting up, and pericardial friction rub on auscultation. The laboratory studies demonstrate a hemolytic anemia as suggested by the reticulocytosis, elevated lactate dehydrogenase, and unconjugated (indirect) hyperbilirubinemia.  

 In general, the possible clinical manifestations of SLE include: 
  •  Fever 
  •  Hematologic 
  •  Neuropsychiatric 
  •  Mucocutaneous 
  •  Serosal 
  •  Musculoskeletal 
  •  Renal 
 


This patient exhibits 1) fever, 2) hematologic involvement, 3) serosal involvement (pericarditis), and likely 4) renal involvement, given her edema, which would be evidenced by proteinuria and a low serum protein level. Together, these findings make SLE the most likely diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Elevated fasting blood glucose:
Incorrect: Although diabetes can cause renal damage over time, it would not explain this patient’s pericarditis or hemolytic anemia. Elevated blood sugar level  is not associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).  
❌ Neutropenia:
Incorrect: Although SLE may cause leukopenia and lymphopenia, a low neutrophil count (neutropenia) in isolation is not specifically associated with SLE. 
✅ Proteinuria:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thrombocytosis:
Incorrect: Hematologic effects of SLE include leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and autoimmune hemolysis. SLE is not associated with increased hematologic cell counts, including platelets.
❌ Uremia:
Incorrect: Although increased serum urea nitrogen might result from a decreased glomerular filtration rate in the setting of lupus nephritis, elevated urea nitrogen itself is not associated with SLE.
❌ Elevated cardiac troponin T:
Incorrect: Any patient with concerning chest pain should have an ECG done and cardiac troponin drawn to rule out an acute coronary syndrome. However, this patient’s ECG shows diffuse PR depressions and ST elevations without reciprocal changes that are most consistent with pericarditis, which does not elevate troponin levels.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man is brought to the clinic from a nearby homeless shelter due to fatigue and progressive dyspnea. The patient states he had a remote history of hemoptysis and night sweats many years ago that resolved with a prolonged course of medications received at a clinic. Temperature is 36°C (97.4°F), pulse is 122/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows 3+ edema in the lower extremities and hepatomegaly. Examination of the neck reveals jugular venous distention that fails to subside on inspiration. Cardiac monitor shows a prominent x and y descent in the jugular venous pulse tracing. A chest x-ray is obtained and shown below:  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with constrictive pericarditis, a condition characterized by incomplete filling of the cardiac chambers due to thickening of the pericardium (seen as a line of calcifications over the heart border on the chest radiograph). This patient experiencing homelessness likely had a previous history of tuberculosis infection (hemoptysis, night sweats), a common cause of constrictive pericarditis. Other causes of constrictive cardiomyopathy include post-cardiac surgery or radiation, connective tissue disorder, and miscellaneous causes (e.g., malignancy, trauma, drug-induced, sarcoidosis, uremic pericarditis). Note that some of the causes are common to both restrictive cardiomyopathy and constrictive pericarditis.  

The fibrous thickening of the pericardium forms a rigid, noncompliant cover of the heart, resulting in progressive impairment in cardiac filling with subsequent low cardiac output. The impaired heart filling leads to progressive signs and symptoms of predominantly right heart failure (e.g., pitting edema of the lower extremities, hepatomegaly). Patients often present with fluid overload, ranging from peripheral edema to anasarca, and symptoms related to low cardiac output, such as fatigability and dyspnea on exertion. On physical examination, the majority of patients display elevated jugular venous pressure. Other less common features include pulsus paradoxus, Kussmaul sign (increase or lack of decrease in JVP during inspiration), pericardial knock, peripheral edema, ascites, and/or cachexia. Pericardial knock is a unique feature that can be heard during early diastole. The sound corresponds to the abrupt cessation of ventricular filling due to a constrictive pericardium. Jugular venous pulse tracing typically reveals prominent x and y descent, correlating with the downward displacement of closed tricuspid valves during rapid ventricular ejection and right atrial emptying, respectively.

The diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis is commonly made using echocardiography in patients presenting with high clinical suspicion. Depending on the severity, patients may be treated with medications aimed to reduce the inflammation (colchicine and NSAIDs) or pericardiectomy surgery.      

Option Analysis

❌ Cardiac myxoma:
Incorrect: Cardiac myxoma is the most common cardiac tumor in adults. Myxomas are typically described as a “ball-valve” mass found in the left atrium. Patients often present with fever, weight loss, and possible syncopal episodes. Cardiac auscultation may reveal early diastolic “tumor plop” sound. Cardiac myxoma, however, does not cause calcifications of the myocardium or jugular venous pulse changes, as seen in this patient.    
✅ Constrictive pericarditis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Dilated cardiomyopathy can also present with dyspnea, chest pain and edema. Causes of dilated cardiomyopathy include genetics, substance abuse (e.g., alcohol, cocaine), and certain infections. Dilated cardiomyopathy, however, does not cause calcifications of the myocardium or jugular venous pulse changes, as seen in this patient.   
❌ Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy is the most common cause of death in young athletes. It is caused by hypertrophy of the myocardium. Patients often present with a harsh systolic ejection murmur and a palpable apical impulse, neither of which are seen in this patient.    
❌ Restrictive cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: The presentation of restrictive cardiomyopathy is very similar to constrictive pericarditis, including chest pain, dyspnea, edema, fatigue, and exercise intolerance due to elevations in filling pressures. The history and physical examination may differentiate the cause. Causes of restrictive cardiomyopathy include post-radiation fibrosis, Löffler endocarditis, amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, and hemochromatosis. In contrast to constrictive pericarditis, restrictive cardiomyopathy presents with prominent y descent but blunting of the x descent in the jugular venous pulse. Additionally, an echocardiogram may reveal an increase in wall thickness, rather than the calcifications on chest radiograph seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, and chest pain. She also states that she has to use 3 pillows at night when she sleeps. Past medical history includes carcinoma of the breast, for which she received surgery and adjuvant radiation therapy but no chemotherapy. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/68. Physical exam shows jugular venous distension and bilateral leg edema. Cardiac auscultation shows S3 and S4 heart sounds. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows low amplitude signals. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s disease?

choices.text: Global dilation of the heart chambers

questions.solution:
This patient with dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea, chest pain, past medical history of breast cancer treated with radiation therapy, and low amplitude electrocardiogram most likely has restrictive cardiomyopathy due to post-radiation myocardial fibrosis. Radiation generates reactive oxygen species in the tissue; over time, this leads to inflammation and can cause myocardial fibrosis.  

Restrictive cardiomyopathy, which is the least common type of cardiomyopathy, is characterized by rigid ventricles which are unable to stretch appropriately and fill with blood. Therefore, the patient will have diastolic dysfunction with normal systolic function.  

Causes of restrictive cardiomyopathy include: 
  •  Genetic: Familial amyloid cardiomyopathy (genetic mutation transthyretin protein) 
  •  Infiltrative: Senile cardiac amyloidosis (transthyretin misfolding with age), iron (hemochromatosis), sarcoidosis 
  •  Other: Post-radiation myocardial fibrosis, scleroderma  



Diagnosis of restrictive cardiomyopathy is achieved via electrocardiogram (ECG), which shows low amplitude signals and short QRS complexes.

Treatment of restrictive cardiomyopathy includes treatment of the underlying cause if possible, loop diuretics, beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, and angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors. However, heart transplant is the only definitive treatment.    

Option Analysis

❌ Global dilation of the heart chambers:
Incorrect: Global dilation of the heart chambers is associated with dilated cardiomyopathy. Dilated cardiomyopathy is associated with chemotherapy (doxorubicin), not radiation therapy. This patient has restrictive cardiomyopathy.  
❌ Myocardial amyloid deposition:
Incorrect: Myocardial amyloid deposition is a cause of restrictive cardiomyopathy, but this patient’s history of breast cancer with radiation therapy suggests post-radiation myocardial fibrosis as the most likely cause.   
✅ Myocardial fibrosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Granulomatous disease:
Incorrect: Granulomatous disease of the heart associated with sarcoidosis is a cause of restrictive cardiomyopathy, but this patient’s history of breast cancer with radiation therapy suggests post-radiation myocardial fibrosis as the most likely cause.   
❌ Myocardial iron deposition:
Incorrect: Myocardial iron deposition associated with hereditary hemochromatosis is a cause of restrictive cardiomyopathy, but this patient’s history of breast cancer with radiation therapy suggests post-radiation myocardial fibrosis as the most likely cause.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to progressive fatigue and shortness of breath for the past few hours. A week ago, she had an upper respiratory infection, and since then, she has not recovered completely. Medical history is significant for smoking half-a-pack of cigarettes daily and drinking 3 beers a week but is otherwise unremarkable. Medications include oral contraceptives and ibuprofen for occasional migraine headaches. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 122/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals jugular venous distension. When the patient inhales, the radial pulse suddenly becomes undetectable. The lungs are clear to auscultation, and no wheezes are heard. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of progressive fatigue, shortness of breath, jugular venous distension, and pulsus paradoxus following a viral illness is consistent with cardiac tamponade.   

Cardiac tamponade occurs when large amounts of fluid accumulate between the layers of the pericardium (pericardial effusion), resulting in compression of the heart. Common etiologies include infectious, trauma, metabolic, autoimmune, cancer or idiopathic. The presentation may be acute and develop over minutes (e.g. trauma) or subacute, which develops over hours to days (e.g., uremia, post-viral) when enough fluid accumulates. The classic triad of symptoms, known as the Beck triad, consists of hypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds. Other signs and symptoms include syncope, chest pain, and pulsus paradoxus.  

Pulsus paradoxus refers to an abnormal decrease in the systolic blood pressure (>10 mmHg) observed during inspiration. It is important to note, however, that pulsus paradoxus can also be seen in some cases of hypovolemic shock and acute and chronic pulmonary obstructive disease. Pulsus paradoxus occurs as a result of the limited outward expansion of the right ventricle as the preload is increased during inspiration. This leads to bulging of the interventricular septum into the left ventricle with reduction in left ventricular filling, which decreases the stroke volume. The reduced stroke volume manifests as a drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration.  

Patients suspected of cardiac tamponade should be promptly evaluated with an electrocardiogram, chest radiograph, and echocardiography. Electrocardiogram typically shows normal sinus tachycardia and electrical alternans, which is characterized by beat-to-beat variations in the amplitude of the QRS complex. Echocardiography plays a major role in identification of pericardial effusion. Definitive treatment includes drainage by needle (pericardiocentesis) or surgery.  

Option Analysis

❌ Viral myocarditis:
Incorrect: The clinical presentation of myocarditis is highly variable, ranging from subclinical disease to fatigue, chest pain, heart failure, arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, and sudden death. Weak pulses may be observed in patients with myocarditis, as the dilated heart cannot efficiently pump out the blood; however, pulsus paradoxus is not observed.   
❌ Myocardial infarction:
Incorrect: Acute myocardial infarction typically presents with chest pain that radiates to the jaw and left shoulder, diaphoresis, and dyspnea. It may progress to cardiogenic shock, which is characterized by tachycardia, hypotension, jugular venous distention, and pulmonary edema. However, it does not cause pulsus paradoxus, and this patient's age favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Cardiac tamponade:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Pulmonary embolism:
Incorrect: Pulmonary embolism can present with shortness of breath, hypotension, and jugular venous distension. Although pulsus paradoxus can also rarely be seen, patients typically have hypoxemia, which is not seen in this patient.   
❌ Constrictive pericarditis:
Incorrect: Constrictive pericarditis shares many common features with cardiac tamponade, including pulsus paradoxus, jugular venous distension, and diastolic dysfunction. Constrictive pericarditis can occur as a result of viral, post-cardiac surgery, post-radiation therapy, connective tissue disorder or idiopathic. However, it is unlikely to develop after 1 week of viral illness, and other features would be expected (ascites, pulsatile hepatomegaly).

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male currently experiencing homelessness presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, shortness of breath and cough of 4-days duration. The patient reports he has also noticed several new skin lesions that were not present before, some of which are painful to the touch. The patient uses intravenous heroin and reports he last used heroin yesterday. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 100/62 mmHg. On physical examination the patient appears disheveled. Erythematous lesions are noted on the chest, arms, and hands bilaterally, some of which are painful to palpation. An image of the non-tender lesions is demonstrated below. Nail examination is notable for small ecchymotic lesions of the upper nail beds bilaterally. Rales are appreciated in the lungs bilaterally, and a holosystolic murmur is appreciated at the left lower sternal border. Which of the following clinical features is required for the diagnosis of this patient’s condition?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
A new murmur that provides evidence of valvular regurgitation is the strongest clinical finding for bacterial endocarditis according to the modified Duke criteria, which is used in the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. This set of clinical and radiographic criteria has been used as the primary diagnostic criteria for endocarditis since its publication in 2000. Of all the clinical factors listed, a new regurgitant murmur is the only major clinical criteria suggestive of bacterial endocarditis.   

All of the other clinical features of endocarditis are listed as minor criteria, including fever, vascular phenomena like Janeway lesions, or immunologic phenomena like Osler nodes, which are the painful erythematous lesions seen in this patient. Subungual nail bed hemorrhage, also referred to as splinter hemorrhages, can also be seen in bacterial endocarditis; however, neither their presence nor location are diagnostic of infective endocarditis, as they are commonly found in otherwise healthy patients or in patients with underlying malignancy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Non-painful erythematous lesions:
Incorrect: Janeway lesions are relatively uncommon lesions found in endocarditis and are classified as minor Duke criteria when assessing a patient for signs of endocarditis.  
❌ Painful erythematous lesions:
Incorrect: Osler nodes are tender subcutaneous violaceous nodules mostly on the pads of the fingers and toes that are classified as minor Duke criteria when assessing a patient for signs of endocarditis.  
✅ Evidence of valvular regurgitation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Fever:
Incorrect: While fever is the most common symptom in endocarditis (found in >90% of cases), it is nonspecific and therefore does not fall under the major Duke criteria when assessing for features of endocarditis.   
❌ Nail bed hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Splinter hemorrhages, while found in endocarditis, are relatively non-specific for this disease process and are also found in patients with underlying malignancy and hypercoagulable disorders. Therefore, they are not included in the major Duke criteria.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents to the cardiologist with a several week history of fatigue, shortness of breath, fever, and chills. The patient underwent catheter-directed ablation for medication resistant atrial fibrillation six days ago. He additionally reports he recently underwent a root canal procedure several weeks ago. Past medical history is significant for rheumatic heart disease, mitral valve prolapse, mitral valve repair, and atrial fibrillation. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6 °F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 122/63 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a holosystolic murmur heard at the cardiac apex. A surgical incision site over the patient’s left neck shows no erythema, discharge, or swelling. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum 
 Hemoglobin  13.5 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  40.5% 
 Leukocyte count  14,100/mm3 
 Platelet count  400,000/mm3 
 ESR                    34 mm/hr 
 CRP  6 mg/L 
Microbiology 
Blood cultures  Gram-positive, coagulase-negative bacteria in 3 consecutive plates  
 Which of the following is the most commonly affected structure in this disease process?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has multiple risk factors for the development of endocarditis including valvular damage, a recent invasive cardiac procedure, and a recent dental procedure without antibiotic prophylaxis.  Of these, the patient likely has endocarditis due to Staphylococcus epidermidis from the recent ablation given the findings of a blood culture positive for a Gram-positive, coagulase-negative bacteria. In these instances of subacute endocarditis, the mitral valve is the most common site of initial infection.  

In contrast, in endocarditis due to a Gram-positive, coagulase-positive bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus, the tricuspid valve is the most common site of infection. This bacteria is commonly acquired through IV drug use, recurrent hemodialysis, or through a central venous access catheter. Other organisms implicated in tricuspid valve infections include Pseudomonas and Candida.    

Option Analysis

❌ Pulmonary veins :
Incorrect: While the pulmonary veins may be implicated in further transmission of vegetations from endocarditis, they are not the most commonly affected site.
❌ Tricuspid valve:
Incorrect: The tricuspid valve is the most commonly affected valve in endocarditis due to Staphylococcus aureus in the setting of intravenous drug use, since this valve is the first encountered by bacteria traveling through the venous system. However, this patient’s endocarditis is of a different etiology.
❌ Aortic valve:
Incorrect: The aortic valve may become implicated in bacterial endocarditis due to S. epidermidis; however, it is not the most common initial site of infection.
✅ Mitral valve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pulmonic valve:
Incorrect: The pulmonic valve may become implicated in bacterial endocarditis due to S. epidermidis; however, it is not the most common initial site of infection.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of progressively worsening fatigue, dyspnea, and lightheadedness for the past 6 months and leg swelling for the last month. She has not had any prior episodes of syncope or chest pain with exertion. Past medical history includes anorexia nervosa. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg. Body mass index is 14.5 kg/m2. Physical examination shows a thin woman in respiratory distress and neck examination shows jugular venous distention. Cardiac auscultation shows a holosystolic blowing murmur that radiates to the axilla and an S3 heart sound that is best heard at the apex in early diastole. A chest x-ray is obtained, and the results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s findings on cardiac auscultation?

choices.text: Increased blood flow through the pulmonic valve
Increased blood flow during ventricular filling
Forceful atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle

questions.solution:
This patient with fatigue, dyspnea, an S3 heart sound, enlarged heart shadow on X-ray, past medical history of anorexia nervosa, and low BMI likely has dilated cardiomyopathy secondary to a thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency resulting in wet beriberi. Thiamine is heavily involved in energy generation, especially during oxidative metabolism. Since cardiac tissue relies on oxidative metabolism, deficiency of vitamin B1 can lead to dysfunction and eventually dilated cardiomyopathy. The S3 heart sound is best heard in early diastole and is due to increased blood flow during ventricular filling.  

Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), which is defined as dilation of all four chambers of the heart, is the most common cause of cardiomyopathy and makes up about 90% of cardiomyopathy cases. The dilation of the heart chambers leads to thinning of the walls of the heart and decreased strength of contraction. Therefore, the patient has systolic dysfunction and normal diastolic function.  

 


The majority of dilated cardiomyopathy is idiopathic, but there are many possible causes that must be ruled out. Causes of dilated cardiomyopathy include: 
  •  Genetic mutations: Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), hemochromatosis 
  •  Systemic conditions: Thyrotoxicosis, peripartum cardiomyopathy, wet beriberi (caused by thiamine deficiency) 
  •  Infectious: Myocarditis, Coxsackievirus B, Chagas disease 
  •  Toxic: Chronic alcoholism, chemotherapy (doxorubicin, daunorubicin), cocaine abuse 
 Diagnosis of dilated cardiomyopathy is achieved via radiographic examination with x-ray and echocardiography. X-ray may show cardiomegaly, pulmonary edema, and pleural effusion. Echocardiography shows ventricular dilation and decreased ejection fraction.  

Possible complications of dilated cardiomyopathy include systolic heart failure, arrhythmias, and valve regurgitation.    

An angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB), or beta blocker may be used to help slow disease progression, but a left ventricular assist device (LVAD) may be necessary, and the most severe cases require heart transplant.   

Option Analysis

❌ Decreased mitral valve leaflet motion:
Incorrect: Decreased mitral valve leaflet motion is associated with the opening snap characteristic of mitral stenosis. It would not be observed in this patient with dilated cardiomyopathy.   
❌ Increased blood flow through the pulmonic valve:
Incorrect: Increased blood flow through the pulmonic valve results in fixed splitting of the S2 heart sound. Fixed splitting is associated with left-to-right shunts, such as atrial septal defect (ASD). It would not be observed in this patient with dilated cardiomyopathy.   
✅ Increased blood flow during ventricular filling:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Delayed right ventricular emptying:
Incorrect: Delayed right ventricular emptying results in wide splitting of the S2 heart sound. Wide splitting is associated with pulmonic stenosis and right bundle branch block. It would not be observed in this patient with dilated cardiomyopathy.   
❌ Forceful atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle  :
Incorrect: Forceful atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle causes an S4 heart sound, which is associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and best heard in late diastole.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus, end-stage kidney disease on dialysis, diabetes, and hypertension presents to the emergency department with a two day history of fever, chills, and dyspnea on exertion. The patient reports he receives dialysis 3 times/week and has not missed any of his scheduled appointments. He last received dialysis two days ago. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 90/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. On physical examination the patient is ill-appearing. There are erythematous lesions noted on the chest and arms bilaterally, as well as a fistula with a palpable thrill in the left arm without evidence of overlying erythema, discharge, or excoriation. A holosystolic murmur is appreciated at the lower left sternal border. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of this patient’s disease process?

choices.text: Subacute deposition of sterile platelet thrombi over heart valves
Rapid bacteremia and acquisition of large vegetations on previously normal valves
Subacute bacteremia and acquisition of small vegetations on previously damaged valves
Seeding of a Gram-positive organism into the bloodstream from the urologic tract
Seeding of a Gram-positive organism into the bloodstream from the gastrointestinal tract

questions.solution:
Acute endocarditis is most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus due to its high virulence.  It classically presents with the rapid development of fever, chills, shortness of breath, and signs of septic shock following inoculation. The infection leads to deposition of large vegetations on previously normal heart valves. The patient with a history of dialysis likely obtained the organism from a recent dialysis session where proper aseptic technique was not performed while accessing the fistula. Other patients at high risk for acute endocarditis include patients with IV drug use and those with central venous catheters that are frequently accessed.  

In contrast, subacute endocarditis most commonly occurs due to viridans group streptococci following dental procedures, as this group of organisms is highly prevalent as oral flora. This group of bacteria typically form smaller vegetations on previously damaged or prosthetic valves. Additionally, subacute endocarditis tends to have a slow, indolent presentation, causing fatigue, weakness, chills, and a new murmur over weeks to months. Other bacteria implicated in subacute endocarditis include Enterococcus faecalis, Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Coxiella burnetii.   

Option Analysis

❌ Subacute deposition of sterile platelet thrombi over heart valves:
Incorrect: This answer is the pathogenesis that describes Libman-Sacks endocarditis, or marantic endocarditis, which commonly occurs in patients with underlying lupus or malignancy. This form of endocarditis, while possible in this patient given the history of lupus, tends to progress slowly over weeks, in contrast to the rapid onset of symptoms as seen in this patient.  
✅ Rapid bacteremia and acquisition of large vegetations on previously normal valves:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Subacute bacteremia and acquisition of small vegetations on previously damaged valves:
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathogenesis of subacute endocarditis, which commonly occurs due to infection with viridans streptococci following dental procedures, Staphylococcus epidermidis following invasive cardiac procedures, or Enterococcus faecalis following indwelling catheter placement. This form of endocarditis tends to progress over weeks to months, as opposed to days as in this patient.   
❌ Seeding of a Gram-positive organism into the bloodstream from the urologic tract:
Incorrect: This answer describes the pathogenesis of endocarditis due to Enterococcus faecalis, which results after invasive urologic or abdominal procedures. It presents with the typical features of subacute endocarditis including malaise, fatigue, and a new murmur over a period of weeks to months.   
❌ Seeding of a Gram-positive organism into the bloodstream from the gastrointestinal tract:
Incorrect: This describes the pathogenesis of endocarditis due to Streptococcus gallolyticus, also known as Streptococcus bovis, which has a high association in patients with underlying colorectal cancer. It presents with the typical features of subacute endocarditis including malaise, fatigue, and a new murmur over a period of weeks to months.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man presents to the cardiologist's office for a follow-up visit after placement of a dual chamber pacemaker three weeks ago for heart failure. The patient’s hospital course was uncomplicated, but the patient is now complaining of worsening dyspnea on exertion, malaise, and fevers. He has a history of mitral valve replacement due to rheumatic heart disease at the age of 55. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 146/73 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex. There is a surgical incision site over the lateral chest wall without evidence of erythema, discharge, or swelling. Small, subcutaneous, tender nodules on the left hand are demonstrated below:  

 
Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Blood is drawn and sent for culture. Three days later, 3 of 4 blood cultures obtained on admission grow Gram-positive, coagulase-negative bacteria. Which of the following virulence factors of this organism is implicated in this patient’s disease process?

choices.text: Pilus allowing adherence to colonic epithelium
Formation of adherent water-soluble glycans from the disaccharide sucrose in dental caries
Anchoring adhesion proteins for oral epithelial tissue

questions.solution:
Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common cause of endocarditis in patients with previously damaged or prosthetic heart valves, and infection often occurs in patients that have recently undergone invasive cardiac procedures. The patient in this vignette recently underwent surgery for placement of a dual chamber pacemaker, the likely nidus for exposure of infection. The history and physical examination are consistent with infective endocarditis (IE), given the presence of fevers, a new murmur, and Osler nodes, as seen in the image.  

Patients with subacute bacterial endocarditis present with a chronic history of nonspecific symptoms. Fever is the most common symptom in IE, and it is often associated with chills, anorexia, and weight loss. Relatively uncommon clinical manifestations, yet pathognomonic of IE, include Janeway lesions (nontender erythematous macules on the palms and soles), Osler nodes (tender subcutaneous violaceous nodules on the pads of the fingers and toes), and Roth spots (exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina).  

S. epidermidis is a part of normal human skin flora and generally has low virulence. However, when the bacteria gain access to the heart or blood stream through indwelling devices, they can cause significant infection. The ability of the bacteria to form biofilms on devices makes treating the infection with antibiotics alone a difficult endeavor. The nidus for infection, the indwelling device or line, should be removed to ensure resolution of the infection.   

Option Analysis

❌ Enzyme converting fibrinogen into fibrin:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus carries the coagulase protein, which helps to clot plasma and enhance its adherence within the cardiovascular system. This bacteria is a common cause of endocarditis due to IV drug use as well as during the initial months following a cardiac procedure, and it tends to cause acute endocarditis. However, this patient’s blood culture grew coagulase-negative bacteria, making S. aureus unlikely.   
❌ Pilus allowing adherence to colonic epithelium:
Incorrect: Streptococcus bovis is a potential cause of endocarditis in patients with underlying colon cancer and inflammatory bowel disease. The bacteria carries a pilus which allows for its adherence to colonic epithelium as well as other host cells.  
❌ Formation of adherent water-soluble glycans from the disaccharide sucrose in dental caries:
Incorrect: Streptococcus mutans is part of the viridans streptococci group of organisms that commonly cause endocarditis after dental procedures due to their predominance as oral flora. It is able to form water-adherent glycans, allowing it to preside as dental flora causing dental caries. This patient has had no recent dental procedures, making this causal pathogen unlikely.   
❌ Anchoring adhesion proteins for oral epithelial tissue:
Incorrect: Streptococcus sanguineous is part of the viridans streptococci group of organisms that commonly cause endocarditis after dental procedures due to their predominance as oral flora. These bacteria contain anchoring adhesion proteins, allowing them to exist as oral flora. This patient has had no recent dental procedures, making this causal pathogen unlikely.   
✅ Biofilm formation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a 6-week history of malaise, chills, and fevers. He additionally has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss over this same time period. His past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, as well as a known mitral valve prolapse. The patient reports he has otherwise been in his usual state of health and endorses compliance with his home medication regimen. He has a past surgical history of total hip replacement at 61, as well as a molar tooth extraction two months ago. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for a 3/6 holosystolic murmur present at the apex that radiates to the left axilla. Blood is drawn and sent for culture. Three days later, 3 of 4 blood cultures obtained on admission grow Gram-positive, alpha-hemolytic bacteria. Which of the following is the most likely pathogen implicated in this patient’s disease process?
questions.solution:
Subacute bacterial endocarditis is commonly caused by bacteria from the group of viridans streptococci, which includes the organisms S. mutans and S. sanguineous. Viridans streptococci are found in abundance as normal oral flora, and if they gain access to the bloodstream via dental procedures or persistent gum bleeding from gingivitis, they can cause subacute bacterial endocarditis in patients with preexisting cardiac lesions.  

As the name implies, subacute bacterial endocarditis progresses slowly, with symptoms often taking weeks to months to manifest. Subacute bacterial endocarditis tends to affect native, diseased heart valves. Previously, rheumatic heart disease was the most common disorder in developed countries as the leading cardiac lesion in patients with infective endocarditis; however, over the last few decades, mitral valve prolapse has replaced this as the most common underlying cardiac lesion. The patient in this vignette has known mitral valve prolapse.  

Patients with subacute bacterial endocarditis present with a chronic history of nonspecific symptoms. Fever is the most common symptom in infective endocarditis (IE), and it is often associated with chills, anorexia, and weight loss. Relatively uncommon clinical manifestations, yet pathognomonic of IE, include Janeway lesions (nontender erythematous macules on the palms and soles), Osler nodes (tender subcutaneous violaceous nodules on the pads of the fingers and toes), and Roth spots (exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina).  

Option Analysis

❌ Staphylococcus aureus  :
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is the most commonly implicated bacteria causing endocarditis in patients with IV drug use, and it most commonly affects the tricuspid valve. Involvement of the tricuspid valve typically presents with tricuspid regurgitation, which results in a new-onset holosystolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. It typically causes a more acute and rapidly progressive infection, and therefore this patient’s more subacute disease process is less suggestive of S. aureus as the cause. Moreover, S. aureus is beta-hemolytic on blood agar, not alpha-hemolytic.   
❌ Streptococcus bovis:
Incorrect: Streptococcus bovis is a common cause of endocarditis in patients with underlying colorectal cancer. However, S. bovis is a Gram-positive, gamma-hemolytic bacteria on blood agar.   
✅ Streptococcus mutans:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Coxiella burnetii:
Incorrect: Coxiella burnetii can cause endocarditis in the setting of patients with a history of contact with livestock. This patient lacks the occupational risk factors that would increase his exposure to this pathogen; additionally, C. burnetti is a Gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacterial pathogen, making it extremely difficult to culture on agar.  
❌ Bartonella henselae:
Incorrect: Bartonella henselae causes a disease known as cat scratch fever and can present as endocarditis in the setting of a history of a cat bite/scratch with painful lymphadenopathy. This patient lacks the risk factors that would increase his exposure to this pathogen; additionally, C. burnetti is a Gram-negative organism.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician with a 2-month history of worsening   weakness, fatigue, and cough. The patient reports the cough is non-productive and notes some shortness of breath on exertion. Medical history is notable for rheumatic heart disease when she was 7 years old. A screening colonoscopy performed at age 50 showed no polyps or abnormalities. She currently works as a cattle rancher at a nearby farm. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F) , pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 122/63 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Cardiopulmonary examination is notable for holosystolic murmur appreciated at the cardiac apex as well as bibasilar rales. Nail examination is notable for small ecchymotic lesions of the upper nail beds bilaterally. Follow-up blood cultures are negative. Which of the following is the most likely organism implicated in this patient’s disease process?
questions.solution:
Endocarditis due to Coxiella burnetii is a rare occurrence but should be considered in patients presenting with symptoms of endocarditis, atypical pneumonia, and a history of exposure to cattle, sheep, or the amniotic fluid of farm animals. C. burnetii is thus classified as a zoonotic infection because it spreads from mammals to humans.  

C. burnetii is a Gram-negative rod that causes a disease called Q fever, which is an atypical pneumonia; if left untreated it can progress to endocarditis, especially in patients with underlying heart valve disease, such as this patient with a history of rheumatic heart disease. It has the ability to form endospores, which is a dormant form in which the bacteria is transmitted in aerosolized form.

The presentation of endocarditis due to C. burnetii is similar to other pathogens that cause subacute presentations and includes fatigue, weakness, chills, or splinter hemorrhages, such as in this patient. Blood cultures for this pathogen are often negative, making it a common cause of culture-negative endocarditis along with the HACEK organisms (Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella), Bartonella, and Candida.     

Option Analysis

❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of endocarditis due to IV drug use and tends to cause acute endocarditis affecting the tricuspid valve more often than the mitral valve. This patient's murmur is heard at the cardiac apex, which is more reflective of mitral regurgitation. Additionally, blood cultures would typically grow Gram-positive bacteria in clusters, as opposed to this patient’s negative culture results.  
❌ Streptococcus bovis:
Incorrect: Streptococcus bovis is a common cause of endocarditis in patients with underlying colon cancer. This patient had no lesions on the last colonoscopy 5 years ago, and the culture-negative results would be atypical, as S. bovis is a Gram-positive bacteria that normally grows on culture.   
❌ Streptococcus mutans:
Incorrect: Streptococcus mutans is part of the viridans streptococci group of organisms that commonly cause endocarditis after dental procedures due to their predominance as oral flora. This patient’s culture-negative results would be atypical, as S. mutans is a Gram-positive bacteria that normally grows on culture.  
✅ Coxiella burnetii:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Streptococcus sanguineous:
Incorrect: Streptococcus sanguineous is part of the viridans streptococci group of organisms that commonly cause endocarditis after dental procedures due to their predominance as oral flora. This patient’s culture-negative results would be atypical, as S. sanguineous is a Gram-positive bacteria that normally grows on culture.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, and cough of three days duration. The patient uses intravenous heroin regularly and reports he last used heroin earlier today. He is currently living in a homeless shelter. Temperature of 38.7 °C (101.6 °F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 100/63 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears disheveled. Erythematous lesions are noted on the chest and arms bilaterally. Rales are appreciated in the lungs bilaterally, and a holosystolic murmur is appreciated at the left lower sternal border. Laboratory values are demonstrated below:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
Complete Blood Count, Serum 
 Hemoglobin  12.5 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  40.5% 
 Leukocyte count  18,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  250,000/mm3 
Inflammatory Markers, Serum 
ESR                 44 mm/hr 
 CRP  18 mg/L 
Electrolytes, Serum 
                  Sodium                131 mEq/L 
               Potassium                 3.6 mEq/L 
                 Chloride                 94 mEq/L  
              Bicarbonate                 20 mEq/L 
                 Calcium                8.4 mg/dL 
Blood is drawn and sent for culture, and the patient is started on empiric antibiotics. Three days later, 3 of 4 blood cultures obtained on admission grow Gram-positive, coagulase-positive bacteria. Which of the following is the most common initial site of infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Infective endocarditis due to Staphylococcus aureus (Gram-positive, coagulase-positive bacteria) is the most common cause of endocarditis in resource-rich settings. Risk factors for acquisition include intravascular catheter placement, history of prosthetic heart valves, and IV drug use, as in this patient.  

The most common site of origin of infective endocarditis due to S. aureus is the tricuspid valve. This is because the bacteria typically gain access primarily through the venous system and initially come in contact with the tricuspid valve as they circulate through the cardiovascular system. This seeding can present as a new-onset murmur in patients, typically heard as a holosystolic murmur appreciated at the left lower sternal border. After attachment to the tricuspid valve, bacterial emboli can mobilize, causing septic emboli to the lungs that result in symptoms of cough, pleuritic chest pain, fever, and hemoptysis.

Option Analysis

❌ Pulmonary veins :
Incorrect: While the pulmonary veins may be implicated in further transmission of vegetations from endocarditis, they are not the most common site of origin for Staphylococcus aureus endocarditis.  
✅ Tricuspid valve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Aortic valve:
Incorrect: The aortic valve may become implicated in bacterial endocarditis due to Staphylococcus aureus, especially in the setting of bicuspid aortic valve or after a valve repair; however, it is not the most common initial site of infection.  
❌ Mitral valve:
Incorrect: The mitral valve is overall the most common site of infection in subacute endocarditis and may become implicated in bacterial endocarditis due to Staphylococcus aureus; however, it is not the most common initial site due to this bacteria.  
❌ Pulmonic valve:
Incorrect: The pulmonic valve may become implicated in bacterial endocarditis due to Staphylococcus aureus; however, it is not the most common initial site of infection.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a several week history of malaise, subjective fevers, and fatigue. He has a history of renal cell carcinoma diagnosed 5 months ago. The patient reports he had a recent stent placed in the left ureter approximately two months ago due to worsening metastatic disease burden. The hospital course was complicated by damage to the ureter, which was repaired surgically. Temperature is 37.7 °C (100.6 °F) , pulse is 102/min, respirations are 22/min and blood pressure is 130/62 mmHg. On physical examination the patient is noted to have conjunctival pallor. A new holosystolic murmur is appreciated at the cardiac apex. Which of the following is the most common organism implicated in this patient’s disease process?
questions.solution:
Infective endocarditis (IE) due to Enterococcus faecalis most commonly results after invasive urologic or abdominal procedures that allow seeding of the organism into the bloodstream. Enterococci are normal colonizers of the gastrointestinal and urologic tracts and can attach to heart valves causing symptoms of endocarditis. This patient likely acquired E. faecalis from the recent urologic surgery.  
Endocarditis due to Enterococcus faecalis can cause all of the same symptoms as other pathogens; fever is the most common symptom in IE, and it is often associated with chills, anorexia, and weight loss. Relatively uncommon clinical manifestations, yet pathognomonic of IE, include Janeway lesions (nontender erythematous macules on the palms and soles), Osler nodes (tender subcutaneous violaceous nodules on the pads of the fingers and toes) and Roth spots (exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina).  

Enterococcus faecalis generally has a slow, subacute presentation, and anemia of chronic disease (as evidenced by this patient’s conjunctival pallor) tends to be more prevalent among patients with endocarditis due to this organism.  

Option Analysis

❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of endocarditis due to IV drug use and tends to cause acute endocarditis. It tends to affect the tricuspid valve more often than the mitral valve. This patient's murmur is heard at the cardiac apex, which is more reflective of mitral regurgitation.  
❌ Streptococcus bovis:
Incorrect:Streptococcus bovis is a common cause of endocarditis in patients with underlying colon cancer or inflammatory bowel disease. It is an unlikely cause of this patient’s infective endocarditis.   
❌ Streptococcus mutans :
Incorrect: Streptococcus mutans is part of the viridans streptococci group of organisms that commonly cause endocarditis after dental procedures, due to their predominance as oral flora. This patient had no recent dental procedures.  
❌ Streptococcus sanguineous :
Incorrect: Streptococcus sanguineous is part of the viridans streptococci group of organisms that commonly cause endocarditis after dental procedures due to their predominance as oral flora. This patient had no recent dental procedures.  
✅ Enterococcus faecalis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man experiences a ST-segment myocardial infarction and is admitted for coronary angiography with stent placement in the left anterior descending artery. On day four of hospitalization, he has sudden sharp chest pain that radiates to his neck and shoulders. The pain is exacerbated by coughing and deep breathing. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a restless man whose symptoms improve when sitting forward from a supine position. There is a loud rubbing sound upon cardiac auscultation when he leans forward. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. An ECG is shown below. The patient is treated with an antiplatelet drug. Which of the following is a common adverse effect of the anti-platelet medication administered in this patient?


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with sharp and pleuritic chest pain on the 4th day of hospitalization following an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction, in combination with ECG findings of diffuse ST-elevation, is suggestive of peri-infarction pericarditis. It is usually managed with aspirin, which risks developing gastric ulcers.

Aspirin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) with an antiplatelet effect. It irreversibly inhibits the activity of cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2) via acetylation, thereby preventing the formation of thromboxane A2, which usually helps in platelet adhesion. It is used in several clinical situations to prevent clots from worsening or provide anti-inflammatory effects:
 
  • A dose of 325 mg is used as a loading dose to treat acute strokes and myocardial infarction. A dose of 81 mg tablets is used as the maintenance therapy 
  • A dose of 650 mg - 1 g every 8 hours is indicated for the treatment of pericarditis, followed by gradual taper after resolution of symptoms. 
Common adverse effects of its use include increased risk of bleeding and gastric ulcers.  

Option Analysis

✅ Gastric ulcers:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Neutropenia:
Incorrect: Neutropenia is a rare but serious adverse effect of the ADP receptor inhibitor, ticlopidine. It prevents platelet aggregation by irreversibly blocking ADP (P2Y12) receptor and inhibiting the expression of glycoproteins IIb/IIIa on the platelet surface. Although it is indicated in managing acute coronary syndrome and coronary stenting, this patient’s symptoms indicate post-MI pericarditis, usually treated with aspirin.  
❌ Osteoporosis:
Incorrect: Osteoporosis is a common adverse effect of heparin therapy. An anticoagulant (not antiplatelet) activates antithrombin in the coagulation pathway, which decreases the action of factor IIa (thrombin) and factor Xa. Although heparin is indicated in patients with coronary stent placement, it cannot alleviate the symptoms of pericarditis.  
❌ Skin necrosis:
Incorrect: Skin and tissue necrosis are serious adverse effects of warfarin therapy and is thought to result from small vessel micro thrombosis. Warfarin is an anticoagulant (not antiplatelet), usually administered in patients requiring chronic anticoagulation (e.g., venous thromboembolism prophylaxis, and stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation). It is not indicated in the treatment of pericarditis.  
❌ Hypotension:
Incorrect: Hypotension is a common adverse effect of phosphodiesterase inhibitors (e.g. cilostazol), which inhibits the breakdown of cyclic guanosine monophosphate in the vascular smooth muscle cells, preventing vasoconstriction. They are usually used to treat peripheral artery disease and coronary artery disease and can be combined with aspirin for secondary prevention of ischemic stroke. They are, however, not indicated in the treatment of acute pericarditis.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to shortness of breath. Her symptoms began four hours ago and have progressively worsened. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and right breast adenocarcinoma status-post unilateral mastectomy, which was performed three-months ago. The patient is currently on propranolol, acetaminophen, ondansetron, and chemotherapeutic agents. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 146/82 mmHg. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds in the lower lungs. A PA chest x-ray is ordered and reveals the findings below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication most likely responsible for her current symptoms?
 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient has shortness of breath in the setting of chemotherapeutic treatment and imaging findings revealing pulmonary edema and cardiomegaly. She most likely has dilated cardiomyopathy secondary to anthracycline use.

Anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin, daunorubicin) are a class of antitumor antibiotics used in the treatment of solid tumors (e.g., breath thyroid, lung) as well as leukemias and lymphomas. The medications work via three mechanisms of action: 1) insertion (intercalation) between DNA base pairs to impair RNA synthesis, 2) inhibition of the enzyme topoisomerase II, and 3) generation of free oxygen radicals that damage DNA.

An important side effect is cardiotoxicity secondary to the buildup of free radicals. It often manifests as dilated cardiomyopathy. Since the abnormally dilated heart is no longer effective in pumping blood into the systemic circulation, fluids may accumulate in the lungs and cause pulmonary edema.

Additional side effects of anthracyclines include myelosuppression, impaired wound healing (by decreasing cellular proliferation and regeneration), gastrointestinal distress, and alopecia.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of topoisomerase I  :
Incorrect: Topotecan causes DNA damage by inhibiting the enzyme topoisomerase I. Common toxicities of topotecan include myelosuppression and diarrhea. However, it does not typically cause dilated cardiomyopathy.  
❌ Disruption of microtubules assembly:
Incorrect: Vinca alkaloids (e.g., Vincristine, Vinblastine) inhibit tubulin polymerization, thus inhibiting microtubules assembly. These drugs may cause peripheral neuropathy, constipation, and bone marrow suppression. However, they would not typically cause dilated cardiomyopathy.  
✅ Insertion between DNA base pairs:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of thymidylate synthase:
Incorrect: 6-mercaptopurine is a purine antimetabolite that inhibits the enzyme thymidylate synthase. The medication is associated with myelosuppression, photosensitivity, and hand-foot syndrome (desquamation of the hands and feet). However, it would not typically cause dilated cardiomyopathy.  
❌ Inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase:
Incorrect: Methotrexate inhibits the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase. As a result, cells are unable to produce tetrahydrofolate, which is required for DNA synthesis. Side effects include myelosuppression, hepatotoxicity, and pulmonary fibrosis. However, it would not typically cause dilated cardiomyopathy.
